name: Bisi Bele Bath
history: Bisi Bele Bath is a traditional Kannada dish from Karnataka, South India. The name translates to 'hot lentil rice' in Kannada. This dish is a wholesome combination of rice, lentils, vegetables, and a unique spice blend known as Bisi Bele Bath masala.
description: Bisi Bele Bath is a flavorful and nutritious one-pot meal. It's made with rice, toor dal (pigeon pea lentils), assorted vegetables, tamarind, and a special spice mix, offering a perfect balance of flavors. It's often served with ghee, papad, and raita.

ingredients.item: mixed vegetables (carrots, peas, bell pepper, beans)

instructions.title: Cook Rice and Lentils
instructions.description: Cook the rice and toor dal together in a pressure cooker or pot until soft and mushy.

instructions.title: Prepare Vegetables
instructions.description: In a separate pan, cook the mixed vegetables with a little water until they are soft.

instructions.title: Mix Ingredients
instructions.description: Combine the cooked rice and lentils with the cooked vegetables. Add tamarind paste, Bisi Bele Bath masala, jaggery, and salt. Add water to adjust the consistency and cook for a few more minutes.

instructions.title: Temper the Dish
instructions.description: In a small pan, heat ghee. Add mustard seeds, curry leaves, and asafoetida. When the mustard seeds start to splutter, pour this tempering over the Bisi Bele Bath.

instructions.title: Serve
instructions.description: Serve the Bisi Bele Bath hot, garnished with a dollop of ghee. Accompany with papad and raita.

tips: The consistency of Bisi Bele Bath should be slightly mushy and not too dry.
Roasting the Bisi Bele Bath masala before adding it to the dish can enhance the flavor.
variations: Add a handful of roasted cashews or peanuts for a crunchy texture.
You can also add a bit of coconut milk for a creamy consistency.

storage.shelfLife: Can be refrigerated for up to 2 days.
storage.instructions: Store in an airtight container in the refrigerator.

reheatingInstructions.instruction: Reheat on the stove or in a microwave, adding a little water if necessary to adjust the consistency.

presentationTips: Serve in a traditional earthenware bowl for an authentic look.
Garnish with fresh coriander leaves and a wedge of lemon.
